Stein’s method for negatively associated random variables with applications to second order stationary random fields

Nathakhun Wiroonsri
University of Southern California
Abstract

Let 𝝃=(ξ1,…,ξm)𝝃subscript𝜉1…subscript𝜉𝑚\bm{\xi}=(\xi_{1},\ldots,\xi_{m}) be a negatively associated mean zero random vector with components that obey the bound |ξi|≤B,i=1,…,mformulae-sequencesubscript𝜉𝑖𝐵𝑖1…𝑚|\xi_{i}|\leq B,i=1,\ldots,m, and whose sum W=∑i=1mξi𝑊superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜉𝑖W=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\xi_{i} has variance 1, the bound

d1​(ℒ​(W),ℒ​(Z))≤5​B−5.2​∑i≠jσi​j.subscript𝑑1ℒ𝑊ℒ𝑍5𝐵5.2subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝜎𝑖𝑗\displaystyle d_{1}\big{(}{\cal L}(W),{\cal L}(Z)\big{)}\leq 5B-5.2\sum_{i\not=j}\sigma_{ij}.

is obtained where Z𝑍Z has the standard normal distribution and d1​(⋅,⋅)subscript𝑑1⋅⋅d_{1}(\cdot,\cdot) is the L1superscript𝐿1L^{1} metric. The result is extended to the multidimensional case with the L1superscript𝐿1L^{1} metric replaced by a smooth functions metric. Applications to second order stationary random fields with exponential decreasing covariance are also presented.

1 Introduction

This work is extended from the recent paper [GW18] that focuses only on positive association. Particularly, in this work, we provide non-asymptotic L1superscript𝐿1L^{1} bounds to the normal for negatively associated random fields in ℤdsuperscriptℤ𝑑\mathbb{Z}^{d} using the same technique developed in [GW18]. We recall that the L1superscript𝐿1L^{1}, or Wasserstein, distance between the distributions ℒ​(X)ℒ𝑋{\cal L}(X) and ℒ​(Y)ℒ𝑌{\cal L}(Y) of real valued random variables X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y is given by

d1​(ℒ​(X),ℒ​(Y))=∫−∞∞|P​(X≤t)−P​(Y≤t)|​𝑑t.subscript𝑑1ℒ𝑋ℒ𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑋𝑡𝑃𝑌𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle d_{1}\big{(}{\cal L}(X),{\cal L}(Y)\big{)}=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|P(X\leq t)-P(Y\leq t)|dt. (1)

A random vector 𝝃=(ξ1,…,ξm)∈ℝm𝝃subscript𝜉1…subscript𝜉𝑚superscriptℝ𝑚\bm{\xi}=(\xi_{1},\ldots,\xi_{m})\in\mathbb{R}^{m} is said to be positively associated whenever

Cov​(f​(𝝃),g​(𝝃))≥0Cov𝑓𝝃𝑔𝝃0\displaystyle\mathrm{Cov}\big{(}f(\bm{\xi}),g(\bm{\xi})\big{)}\geq 0

for all real valued coordinate-wise nondecreasing functions f𝑓f and g𝑔g on ℝmsuperscriptℝ𝑚\mathbb{R}^{m} such that f​(𝝃)𝑓𝝃f(\bm{\xi}) and g​(𝝃)𝑔𝝃g(\bm{\xi}) have finite second moments. A random vector 𝝃=(ξ1,…,ξm)∈ℝm𝝃subscript𝜉1…subscript𝜉𝑚superscriptℝ𝑚\bm{\xi}=(\xi_{1},\ldots,\xi_{m})\in\mathbb{R}^{m} is said to be negatively associated if for any disjoint subsets A,B𝐴𝐵A,B of [m]:={1,2,…,m}assigndelimited-[]𝑚12…𝑚[m]:=\{1,2,\ldots,m\},

Cov​(f​(ξi,i∈A),g​(ξj,j∈B))≤0Cov𝑓subscript𝜉𝑖𝑖𝐴𝑔subscript𝜉𝑗𝑗𝐵0\displaystyle\mathrm{Cov}\big{(}f(\xi_{i},i\in A),g(\xi_{j},j\in B)\big{)}\leq 0 (2)

for all coordinate-wise increasing functions f:ℝ|A|→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝐴ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{|A|}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} and g:ℝ|B|→ℝ:𝑔→superscriptℝ𝐵ℝg:\mathbb{R}^{|B|}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} such that f​(ξi,i∈A)𝑓subscript𝜉𝑖𝑖𝐴f(\xi_{i},i\in A) and g​(ξj,j∈B)𝑔subscript𝜉𝑗𝑗𝐵g(\xi_{j},j\in B) have finite second moments. In general, a collection {ξα:α∈I}conditional-setsubscript𝜉𝛼𝛼𝐼\{\xi_{\alpha}:\alpha\in I\} of real valued random variables indexed by a set I𝐼I is said to be positively associated (resp. negatively associated) if all finite subcollections are positively associated (resp. negatively associated). Positive association was introduced in [EPW67] and has been found frequently in probabilistic models in several areas, especially statistical physics. In some literature positive association is termed the ‘FKG-inequality’ or simply ‘association’ (see [New80] and [CG84] for examples). Negative association was later introduced in [JP83] and has well-known applications related to permutation distributions.

Over the last few decades, many researchers established central limit theorems and rates of convergence for sums of positively associated random variables ([New80],[Bir88],[Bul95]) and negatively associated random variables ([LW08],[CW09]) under different assumptions. Recently, the work [GW18] developed an L1superscript𝐿1L^{1} version of Stein’s method adapted to sums of positively associated random variables with applications to statistical physics. Stein’s method, introduced by [Ste72], is nowadays one of the most powerful methods to prove convergence in distribution as it has main advantages that it provides non-asymptotic bounds on the distance between distributions, and that it can handle various situations involving dependence. Thus far, many applications in several areas such as statistics, statistical physics and applied sciences have been developed using this method. For more detail about the method in general, see the text [CGS11] and the introductory notes [Ros11].

The one dimensional result of [GW18] is stated below.

Theorem 1.1 ([GW18])

Let 𝛏=(ξ1,…,ξm)𝛏subscript𝜉1…subscript𝜉𝑚\bm{\xi}=(\xi_{1},\ldots,\xi_{m}) be a positively associated mean zero random vector with components obeying the bound |ξi|≤Bsubscript𝜉𝑖𝐵|\xi_{i}|\leq B for some B>0𝐵0B>0, and whose sum W=∑i=1mξi𝑊superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜉𝑖W=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\xi_{i} has variance 1. Let Z𝑍Z be a standard normal random variable. Then

d1​(ℒ​(W),ℒ​(Z))≤5​B+8π​∑i≠jσi​jwhereσi​j=𝔼​[ξi​ξj].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑1ℒ𝑊ℒ𝑍5𝐵8𝜋subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝜎𝑖𝑗wheresubscript𝜎𝑖𝑗𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗\displaystyle d_{1}\big{(}{\cal L}(W),{\cal L}(Z)\big{)}\leq 5B+\sqrt{\frac{8}{\pi}}\sum_{i\not=j}\sigma_{ij}\quad\mbox{where}\quad\sigma_{ij}=\mathbb{E}[\xi_{i}\xi_{j}].

The multidimensional result was also obtained in [GW18] with the L1superscript𝐿1L^{1} metric replaced by a smooth functions metric, following the development of Chapter 12 of [CGS11].

The results above were applied to second order stationary random fields assuming exponential decreasing covariance and to four models in statistical physics; Ising and voter models, bond percolation and contact process. In the present work, we prove similar results adapted to negative association.

Stein’s method has been used previously for negative association and some related concepts. In [LW08], Stein’s method was used in normal approximation for sums of pairwise negative quadrant dependent random variables which allows one to derive a CLT for pairwise negative quadrant dependent random variables with Lindeberg’s condition. We note that when m=2𝑚2m=2 in (2) negative association and negative quadrant dependent are equivalent (see [JP83]). In [Dal13], Stein’s method was used to obtain the total variation distance between compound Poisson distribution and sums of positively associated or negatively associated random variables.

Our main results in the one dimensional and multidimensional cases are stated in Theorems 1.3 and 1.4, respectively, as follows.

Theorem 1.3

Let 𝛏=(ξ1,…,ξm)𝛏subscript𝜉1…subscript𝜉𝑚\bm{\xi}=(\xi_{1},\ldots,\xi_{m}) be a negatively associated mean zero random vector with components obeying the bound |ξi|≤Bsubscript𝜉𝑖𝐵|\xi_{i}|\leq B for some B>0𝐵0B>0, and whose sum W=∑i=1mξi𝑊superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝜉𝑖W=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\xi_{i} has variance 1. d1​(ℒ​(W),ℒ​(Z))≤5​B−5.2​∑i≠jσi​j.subscript𝑑1ℒ𝑊ℒ𝑍5𝐵5.2subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝜎𝑖𝑗\displaystyle d_{1}\big{(}{\cal L}(W),{\cal L}(Z)\big{)}\leq 5B-5.2\sum_{i\not=j}\sigma_{ij}. (4)

Remark 1.5

We note that the differences between our results in Theorems 1.3 and 1.4 for negative association and those in Theorems 1.1 and 1.2 of [GW18] for positive association, are that the signs of the covariance terms are reverse and that the constants are different. Nevertheless, in Section 3 we have an example where these changes do not contribute rates of convergence. We also note that the bounds in the four theorems above are particularly useful when the variables one handles are bounded and (positively or negatively) associated. However let us compare the one dimensional results in Theorems 1.1 and 1.3 with the classical result for independent and identically distributed variables Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}, i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] with 𝔼​Xi=0𝔼subscript𝑋𝑖0\mathbb{E}X_{i}=0, Var​Xi=σ2>0Varsubscript𝑋𝑖superscript𝜎20\mathrm{Var}X_{i}=\sigma^{2}>0 and |Xi|≤Ksubscript𝑋𝑖𝐾|X_{i}|\leq K for some K>0𝐾0K>0. With W=(∑iXi)/(σ​n)𝑊subscript𝑖subscript𝑋𝑖𝜎𝑛W=\left(\sum_{i}X_{i}\right)/(\sigma\sqrt{n}), both Theorems 1.1 and 1.3 give that d1​(ℒ​(W),ℒ​(Z))≤5​K​σ−1​n−1/2subscript𝑑1ℒ𝑊ℒ𝑍5𝐾superscript𝜎1superscript𝑛12d_{1}\big{(}{\cal L}(W),{\cal L}(Z)\big{)}\leq 5K\sigma^{-1}n^{-1/2}. The classical Berry Esseen theorem provides the bound supx∈ℝ|P​(W≤x)−P​(Z≤x)|≤C​K3​σ−3​n−1/2subscriptsupremum𝑥ℝ𝑃𝑊𝑥𝑃𝑍𝑥𝐶superscript𝐾3superscript𝜎3superscript𝑛12\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}|P(W\leq x)-P(Z\leq x)|\leq CK^{3}\sigma^{-3}n^{-1/2} with the smallest constant C=0.4748𝐶0.4748C=0.4748 obtained recently by [She11]. Though the rates of convergence in n𝑛n are the same, the constants are different and actually the two distances are not comparable as it is known that supx∈ℝ|P​(X≤x)−P​(Y≤x)|≤2​c​d1​(ℒ​(X),ℒ​(Y))subscriptsupremum𝑥ℝ𝑃𝑋𝑥𝑃𝑌𝑥2𝑐subscript𝑑1ℒ𝑋ℒ𝑌\sup_{x\in\mathbb{R}}|P(X\leq x)-P(Y\leq x)|\leq\sqrt{2cd_{1}\big{(}{\cal L}(X),{\cal L}(Y)\big{)}} for some c>0𝑐0c>0 but not conversely (See Proposition 1.2 of [Ros11]).

The remainder of this work is organized as follows. In the next section, we use Stein’s method to prove the two main results, Theorems 1.3 and 1.4. We state our results for negatively associated random fields whose covariance decays exponentially in Section 3 . One similar advantage of the four theorems stated in this section is that, unlike many results based on Stein’s method, they may be applied without the need for coupling constructions.

2 Proofs of main theorems

In this section we prove our main results, Theorems 1.3 and 1.4, using similar techniques as in [GW18]. For this purpose, we first state the following two lemmas proved in [JP83] and [CW09], respectively. The more general version of the first lemma was originally proved in [BS98] in Russian and the English version can be found in the book [BS07]. Lemma 2.1 states that two disjoint sums of negatively associated random variables are negatively associated which will be used throughout the remainder of this work. Lemma 2.2 allows us to bound |Cov(f(ξi:i∈A),g(ξj:j∈B))|\left|\mathrm{Cov}(f(\xi_{i}:i\in A),g(\xi_{j}:j\in B))\right| by a linear combination of −Cov​(ξi,ξj)Covsubscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝜉𝑗-\mathrm{Cov}(\xi_{i},\xi_{j}) with i∈A,j∈Bformulae-sequence𝑖𝐴𝑗𝐵i\in A,j\in B when A𝐴A and B𝐵B are disjoint.

Lemma 2.1 ([JP83])

Increasing functions defined on disjoint subsets of a set of negatively associated random variables are negatively associated.

Lemma 2.2 ([BS98], [CW09])

Let A𝐴A and B𝐵B be disjoint finite sets, and let ξjsubscript𝜉𝑗\xi_{j}, j∈A∪B𝑗𝐴𝐵j\in A\cup B, be negatively associated random variables. If f:ℝ|A|→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝐴ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{|A|}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, g:ℝ|B|→ℝ:𝑔→superscriptℝ𝐵ℝg:\mathbb{R}^{|B|}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} are partially differentiable with bounded partial derivatives, then

|Cov(f(ξi:i∈A),g(ξj:j∈B))|≤−∑i∈A∑j∈B|∂f∂ξi|∞|∂g∂ξj|∞Cov(ξi,ξj).\displaystyle\left|\mathrm{Cov}(f(\xi_{i}:i\in A),g(\xi_{j}:j\in B))\right|\leq-\sum_{i\in A}\sum_{j\in B}\left|\frac{\partial f}{\partial\xi_{i}}\right|_{\infty}\left|\frac{\partial g}{\partial\xi_{j}}\right|_{\infty}\mathrm{Cov}(\xi_{i},\xi_{j}).

We note that the difference between the proofs below and the ones in [GW18] results from that Lemma 2.2 requires A𝐴A and B𝐵B to be disjoint unlike the one for positive association. Therefore we add a few more steps in the proofs to handle this situation. In the proof that follows, we use the alternate form of the L1superscript𝐿1L^{1}, or Wasserstein distance (see e.g. [Rac84]);

d1​(ℒ​(X),ℒ​(Y))=suph∈𝕃|𝔼​h​(X)−𝔼​h​(Y)|where𝕃={h:|h​(y)−h​(x)|≤|y−x|}.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑1ℒ𝑋ℒ𝑌subscriptsupremumℎ𝕃𝔼ℎ𝑋𝔼ℎ𝑌where𝕃conditional-setℎℎ𝑦ℎ𝑥𝑦𝑥\displaystyle d_{1}\big{(}{\cal L}(X),{\cal L}(Y)\big{)}=\sup_{h\in\mathbb{L}}|\mathbb{E}h(X)-\mathbb{E}h(Y)|\quad\mbox{where}\quad\mathbb{L}=\{h:|h(y)-h(x)|\leq|y-x|\}. (6)

3 Applications

In this section, we follow the same structure as in Section 2.1 of [GW18] with positive association replaced by negative association. In particular, we apply our main theorems in the first section to second order stationary negatively associated random fields with exponential covariance decay.

First we introduce the definitions and notations used in [GW18] that will also be used here. Since all norms in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} are equivalent, we use the L1superscript𝐿1L^{1} norm that makes our calculation simplest.

Lemma 3.3

□□\Box

To prove Theorem 3.2, we apply Theorem 1.4 and use the same techniques as in Theorem 3.1. We remind the reader that for this result we do not explicitly compute the constants, but index them by the parameters on which they depend.

Applying Lemma 3.5, for all q∈[p]𝑞delimited-[]𝑝q\in[p] we have

which implies that ΣΣ\Sigma is a strictly diagonally dominant matrix, and is therefore invertible by the Gershgorin circle theorem, see for instance Theorem 15.10 of [BR14]. Another claim in (41) follows from [AN63], where it is shown that the bound (41) holds for the norm ‖C‖∞=maxi​∑j=1p|ci​j|subscriptnorm𝐶subscript𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑝subscript𝑐𝑖𝑗||C||_{\infty}=\max_{i}\sum_{j=1}^{p}|c_{ij}|, which dominates |C|∞subscript𝐶|C|_{\infty}.
